{{Psychology sidebar}} '''Social dominance orientation''' ('''SDO''')<ref name="Sidanius2001">{{cite book|last1=Sidanius |first1= Jim |last2= Pratto |first2= Felicia |year= 2001 |title=Social Dominance: An Intergroup Theory of Social Hierarchy and Oppression |location=Cambridge |publisher= Cambridge University Press | isbn =978-0-521-80540-7 }}{{page needed|date=November 2013}}</ref> is a personality trait which predicts social and political attitudes, and is a widely used [[Social Psychology|social psychological]] scale. SDO is conceptualized as a measure of individual differences in levels of group-based discrimination; that is, it is a measure of an individual's preference for [[hierarchy]] within any [[social system]] and the domination over lower-status groups. It is a predisposition toward anti-[[egalitarianism]] within and between groups. The concept of SDO as a measurable individual difference is a product of [[social dominance theory]].
Individuals who score high in SDO desire to maintain and, in many cases, increase the differences between [[social status]]es of different groups, as well as individual group members. Typically, they are dominant, driven, tough, and seekers of [[Power (social and political)|power]]. People high in SDO also prefer hierarchical group orientations. Often, people who score high in SDO adhere strongly to belief in a "[[wiktionary:dog eat dog|dog-eat-dog]]" world.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1177/0146167202282002 |title=Social Dominance Orientation and Intergroup Bias: The Legitimation of Favoritism for High-Status Groups |year=2002 |last1=Levin |first1=S. |last2=Federico |first2=C. M. |last3=Sidanius |first3=J. |last4=Rabinowitz |first4=J. L. |journal=Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin |volume=28 |issue=2 |pages=144–57}}</ref> It has also been found that men are generally higher than women in SDO measures.<ref>Forsyth, D.R. (2009). ''Ground Dynamics'': New York: Wadsworth [Chapter 7]{{page needed|date=November 2013}}</ref> Studies have found that SDO has a strong positive relationship with [[Authoritarianism|authoritarian]] and [[Racism|racist]] beliefs.<ref name="auth">{{cite journal |url=http://bartduriez.com/documents/PDF/2002_DuriezVanhiel.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150203010927/http://bartduriez.com/documents/PDF/2002_DuriezVanhiel.pdf |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2015-02-03 |title=The march of modern fascism. A comparison of social dominance orientation and authoritarianism |year=2002 |journal=Personality and Individual Differences |volume=32 |issue=7 |pages=1199–1213 |last1=Duriez |first1=Bart |last2=Van Hiel |first2=Alain |doi=10.1016/s0191-8869(01)00086-1 |citeseerx=10.1.1.1005.399 }}</ref>
==Social dominance theory==
SDO was first proposed by Jim Sidanius and Felicia Pratto as part of their [[social dominance theory]] (SDT). SDO is the key measurable component of SDT that is specific to it.
SDT begins with the empirical observation that surplus-producing social systems have a threefold group-based hierarchy structure: age-based, gender-based and "arbitrary set-based", which can include race, class, sexual orientation, caste, ethnicity, religious affiliation, etc. Age-based hierarchies invariably give more power to adults and middle-age people than children and younger adults, and gender-based hierarchies invariably grant more power to one [[gender]] over others, but arbitrary-set hierarchies—though quite resilient—are truly arbitrary.
SDT is based on three primary assumptions:{{citation needed|date=November 2013}} #While age- and gender-based hierarchies will tend to exist within all social systems, arbitrary-set systems of social hierarchy will invariably emerge within social systems producing sustainable economic surpluses. #Most forms of group conflict and oppression (e.g., racism, homophobia, ethnocentrism, sexism, classism, regionalism) can be regarded as different manifestations of the same basic human predisposition to form group-based hierarchies. #Human social systems are subject to the counterbalancing influences of hierarchy-enhancing (HE) forces, producing and maintaining ever higher levels of group-based social inequality, and hierarchy-attenuating (HA) forces, producing greater levels of group-based social equality.
SDO is the individual attitudinal aspect of SDT. It is influenced by group status, socialization, and temperament. In turn, it influences support for HE and HA "legitimating myths", defined as "values, attitudes, beliefs, causal attributions and ideologies" that in turn justify social institutions and practices that either enhance or attenuate group hierarchy.
==Early development== While the correlation of gender with SDO scores has been empirically measured and confirmed,<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1111/j.2044-8309.1997.tb01118.x |title=The gender gap: Differences in political attitudes and social dominance orientation |year=1997 |last1=Pratto |first1=Felicia |last2=Stallworth |first2=Lisa M. |last3=Sidanius |first3=Jim |journal=British Journal of Social Psychology |volume=36 |pages=49–68 |pmid=9114484}}</ref> the impact of temperament and socialization is less clear. Duckitt has suggested a model of attitude development for SDO, suggesting that unaffectionate socialisation in childhood causes a tough-minded attitude. According to Duckitt's model, people high in tough-minded personality are predisposed to view the world as a competitive place in which resource competition is [[zero-sum]]. A desire to compete, which fits with social dominance orientation, influences in-group and outside-group attitudes. People high in SDO also believe that hierarchies are present in all aspects of society and are more likely to agree with statements such as "It's probably a good thing that certain groups are at the top and other groups are at the bottom". In turn, SDO predicts stereotyping, discrimination and prejudice.{{citation needed|date=February 2013}}
==Scale==
SDO has been measured by a series of scales that have been refined over time, all of which contain a balance of pro- and contra-trait statements or phrases. A 7-point [[Likert scale]] is used for each item; participants rate their agreement or disagreement with the statements from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree). Most of the research was conducted with the SDO-5 (a 14-point scale) and SDO-6. The SDO-7 scale is the most recent scale measuring social dominance orientation, which embeds two sub-dimensions: dominance (SDO-D) and anti-egalitarianism (SDO-E).<ref name=":5">{{Cite journal|last=Ho|first=Arnold K.|last2=Sidanius|first2=Jim|last3=Kteily|first3=Nour|last4=Sheehy-Skeffington|first4=Jennifer|last5=Pratto|first5=Felicia|last6=Henkel|first6=Kristin E.|last7=Foels|first7=Rob|last8=Stewart|first8=Andrew L.|title=The nature of social dominance orientation: Theorizing and measuring preferences for intergroup inequality using the new SDO₇ scale.|journal=Journal of Personality and Social Psychology|volume=109|issue=6|pages=1003–1028|doi=10.1037/pspi0000033|pmid=26479362|year=2015}}</ref>
=== SDO-7 items<ref name=":5" /> ===
==== Dominance Sub-Scale ==== # Some groups of people must be kept in their place. # It's probably a good thing that certain groups are at the top and other groups are at the bottom. # An ideal society requires some groups to be on top and others to be on the bottom. # Some groups of people are simply inferior to other groups. # Groups at the bottom are just as deserving as groups at the top. (reverse-scored) # No one group should dominate in society. (reverse-scored) # Groups at the bottom should not have to stay in their place. (reverse-scored) # Group dominance is a poor principle. (reverse-scored)
==== Anti-Egalitarianism Sub-Scale ==== # We should not push for group equality. # We shouldn't try to guarantee that every group has the same quality of life. # It is unjust to try to make groups equal. # Group equality should not be our primary goal. # We should work to give all groups an equal chance to succeed. (reverse-scored) # We should do what we can to equalize conditions for different groups. (reverse-scored) # No matter how much effort it takes, we ought to strive to ensure that all groups have the same chance in life. (reverse-scored) # Group equality should be our ideal. (reverse-scored)
=== SDO-16 items<ref name="Sidanius2001" />===
# Some groups of people are simply inferior to other groups. # In getting what you want, it is sometimes necessary to use force against other groups. # It's OK if some groups have more of a chance in life than others. # To get ahead in life, it is sometimes necessary to step on other groups. # If certain groups stayed in their place, we would have fewer problems. # It's probably a good thing that certain groups are at the top and other groups are at the bottom. # Inferior groups should stay in their place. # Sometimes other groups must be kept in their place. # It would be good if groups could be equal. (reverse-scored) # Group equality should be our ideal. (reverse-scored) # All groups should be given an equal chance in life. (reverse-scored) # We should do what we can to equalize conditions for different groups. (reverse-scored) # Increased social equality is beneficial to society. (reverse-scored) # We would have fewer problems if we treated people more equally. (reverse-scored) # We should strive to make incomes as equal as possible. (reverse-scored) # No group should dominate in society. (reverse-scored)
Keying is reversed on questions 9 through 16, to control for [[acquiescence bias]].
==Criticisms of the construct== Rubin and Hewstone (2004)<ref name=Rubin2004>{{cite journal |doi=10.1111/j.1467-9221.2004.00400.x |title=Social Identity, System Justification, and Social Dominance: Commentary on Reicher, Jost et al., and Sidanius et al |year=2004 |last1=Rubin |first1=Mark |last2=Hewstone |first2=Miles |journal=Political Psychology |volume=25 |issue=6 |pages=823–44}}</ref> argue that social dominance research has changed its focus dramatically over the years, and these changes have been reflected in different versions of the social dominance orientation construct. Social dominance orientation was originally defined as "the degree to which individuals desire social dominance and superiority for themselves and their primordial groups over other groups" (p. 209).<ref name=Sidanius1993>{{cite book |last1=Sidanius |first1=James |chapter=The psychology of group conflict and the dynamics of oppression: A social dominance perspective |chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=Io8pP8ihLg4C&pg=PA183 |editor1-last=Iyengar |editor1-first=Shanto |editor2-last=McGuire |editor2-first=William James |year=1993 |title=Explorations in political psychology. Duke studies in political psychology |pages=183–219 |publisher=Duke University Press |isbn=978-0-8223-1324-3}}</ref> It then quickly changed to not only "(a) a…desire for and value given to in-group dominance over out-groups" but also "(b) the desire for nonegalitarian, hierarchical relationships between groups within the social system" (p. 1007).<ref name=Sidanius1994>{{cite journal |doi=10.1037/0022-3514.67.6.998 |title=Social dominance orientation and the political psychology of gender: A case of invariance? |year=1994 |last1=Sidanius |first1=Jim |last2=Pratto |first2=Felicia |last3=Bobo |first3=Lawrence |journal=Journal of Personality and Social Psychology |volume=67 |issue=6 |pages=998–1011}}</ref> The most recent measure of social dominance orientation (see SDO-6 above) focuses on the "general desire for unequal relations among social groups, regardless of whether this means ingroup domination or ingroup subordination" (p. 312).<ref name=Sidanius>{{cite book |last1=Sidanius |first1=Jim |last2=Levin |first2=Shana |last3=Federico |first3=Christopher M. |last4=Pratt |first4=Felicia |year=2001 |chapter=Legitimizing Ideologies: The Social Dominance Approach |chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=wazaJn0Dh90C&pg=PA307 |pages=307–31 |editor1-first=John T. |editor1-last=Jost |editor2-first=Brenda |editor2-last=Major |title=The Psychology of Legitimacy: Emerging Perspectives on Ideology, Justice, and Intergroup Relations |publisher=Cambridge University Press |isbn=978-0-521-78699-7}}</ref> Given these changes, Rubin and Hewstone believe that evidence for social dominance theory should be considered "as supporting three separate SDO hypotheses, rather than one single theory" (p. 22).<ref name=Rubin2004/>
==Group-based and individual dominance==
Robert Altemeyer said that people with a high SDO want more power (agreeing with items such as "''Winning is more important than how you play the game''") and are more [[Machiavellianism|Machiavellian]] (manipulative and amoral, agreeing with items such as "''There really is no such thing as'' 'right and wrong' and ''It all boils down to what you can get away with''").<ref>{{cite web |url=http://members.shaw.ca/jeanaltemeyer/drbob/TheAuthoritarians.pdf |title=The Authoritarians |page=166 |last=Altemeyer |first=Robert |authorlink=Bob Altemeyer |year=2006 |format=PDF |accessdate=20 March 2016}}{{page needed|date=November 2013}}</ref>
These observations are at odds with conceptualisations of SDO as a group-based phenomenon, suggesting that the SDO reflects interpersonal dominance, not only group-based dominance. This is supported by Sidanius and Pratto's own evidence that high-SDO individuals tend to gravitate toward hierarchy-enhancing jobs and institutions, such as law enforcement, that are themselves hierarchically structured vis-a-vis individuals within them.
==Relations with other personality traits==
===Connection with right wing authoritarianism===
SDO correlates weakly with [[right-wing authoritarianism]] (RWA) ([[Pearson product-moment correlation coefficient|r]] ≈ .18).<ref name=pratto /> Both predict attitudes, such as [[sexist]], [[racist]], and [[Heterosexism|heterosexist]] attitudes.<ref name=Sibley2006>{{cite journal |doi=10.1111/j.1467-9221.2006.00531.x |title=Social Dominance Orientation and Right-Wing Authoritarianism: Additive and Interactive Effects |year=2006 |last1=Sibley |first1=Chris G. |last2=Robertson |first2=Andrew |last3=Wilson |first3=Marc S. |journal=Political Psychology |volume=27 |issue=5 |pages=755–68 |jstor=3792537}}</ref> The two contribute to different forms of prejudice; SDO correlates to higher prejudice against subordinate and disadvantaged groups, RWA correlates to higher prejudice against threatening groups, while both are associated with increases in prejudice for "dissident" groups.<ref name=crawford2013>{{cite journal |doi=10.1111/j.1559-1816.2012.00990.x |title=Right-wing authoritarianism and social dominance orientation differentially predict biased evaluations of media reports |year=2013 |last1=Crawford |first1=Jarret T. |last2=Jussim |first2=Lee |last3=Cain |first3=Thomas R. |last4=Cohen |first4=Florette |journal=Journal of Applied Social Psychology |volume=43 |pages=163–74}}</ref><ref name=Duckitt2007>{{cite journal |doi=10.1002/per.614 |title=Right wing authoritarianism, social dominance orientation and the dimensions of generalized prejudice |year=2007 |last1=Duckitt |first1=John |last2=Sibley |first2=Chris G. |journal=European Journal of Personality |volume=21 |issue=2 |pages=113–30}}</ref><ref name= Asbrock2009>{{cite journal |doi=10.1002/per.746 |title=Right-wing authoritarianism and social dominance orientation and the dimensions of generalized prejudice: A longitudinal test |year=2009 |last1=Asbrock |first1=Frank |last2=Sibley |first2=Chris G. |last3=Duckitt |first3=John |journal=European Journal of Personality |pages=324–40}}</ref> SDO and RWA contribute to [[prejudice]] in an additive rather than interactive way (the interaction{{clarify|date=May 2012}} of SDO and RWA accounted, in one study, for an average of less than .001% variance in addition to their linear combination), that is the association between SDO and prejudice is similar regardless of a person's level of RWA, and vice versa.<ref name=Sibley2006/> Crawford et al. (2013) found that RWA and SDO differentially predicted interpretations of media reports about socially threatening (for example, gays and lesbians) and disadvantaged groups (for example, African Americans), respectively. Subjects with high SDO, but not RWA, scores reacted positively to articles and authors that opposed [[affirmative action]], and negatively to pro-affirmative-action article content. Moreover, RWA, but not SDO, predicted subjects' evaluations of same-sex relationships, such that high-RWA individuals favored anti-same-sex relationships article content and low-RWA individuals favorably rated pro-same-sex relationships content.<ref name=crawford2013/>
===Correlation with Big Five personality traits===
Studies on the relationship of SDO with the higher order [[Big Five personality traits]] have associated high SDO with lower [[openness to experience]] and lower [[agreeableness]].<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1002/per.526|last1=Ekehammar|first1=Bo|last2=Akrami|first2=Nazar|last3=Gylje|first3=Magnus|last4=Zakrisson|first4=Ingrid|title=What matters most to prejudice: Big Five personality, Social Dominance Orientation, or Right-Wing Authoritarianism?|journal=European Journal of Personality|volume=18|issue=6|pages=463–482|year=2004}}</ref> [[Meta-analysis|Meta-analytic]] aggregation of these studies indicates that the association with low Agreeableness is more robust than the link to Openness to experience.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|title = Right-Wing Authoritarianism and Social Dominance Orientation|journal = Journal of Individual Differences|date = 2006-01-01|issn = 1614-0001|pages = 117–126|volume = 27|issue = 3|doi = 10.1027/1614-0001.27.3.117|first = Nazar|last = Akrami|first2 = Bo|last2 = Ekehammar}}</ref> Individuals low in Agreeableness are more inclined to report being motivated by self-interest and self-indulgence''.''<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Big-Five personality prospectively predicts Social Dominance Orientation and Right-Wing Authoritarianism|url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0191886911003825|journal = Personality and Individual Differences|date = 2012-01-01|pages = 3–8|volume = 52|issue = 1|doi = 10.1016/j.paid.2011.08.009|first = Ryan|last = Perry|first2 = Chris G.|last2 = Sibley}}</ref> They also tend to be more self-centred and are more '[[Psychoticism|tough-minded]]' compared to those who are high on Agreeableness, leading them to perceive the world to be a highly-competitive place, where the way to success is through power and dominance – all of which predict SDO.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|title = Personality and Prejudice: A Meta-Analysis and Theoretical Review|url = http://psr.sagepub.com/content/12/3/248|journal = Personality and Social Psychology Review|date = 2008-08-01|issn = 1088-8683|pmid = 18641385|pages = 248–279|volume = 12|issue = 3|doi = 10.1177/1088868308319226|first = Chris G.|last = Sibley|first2 = John|last2 = Duckitt}}</ref>
Low Openness, by contrast, aligns more strongly with RWA; thinking in clear and straightforward moral codes that dictate how society as a system should function. Being low in Openness prompts the individual to value security, stability and control: fundamental elements of RWA.<ref name=":1" />
==== Facet-level associations ====
In case of SDO all five facets of Agreeableness significantly correlate (negatively), even after controlling for RWA.<ref name=":0" /> 'Tough-mindedness' (opposite of tender-mindedness' facet) is the strongest predictor of SDO. After the effect of SDO is controlled for only one facet of agreeableness is predictive of RWA. {{Citation needed|date = December 2015}} Facets also distinguish SDO from RWA, with 'Dominators' (individuals high on SDO), but not 'authoritarians' (individuals who score high on RWA), having been found to be lower in dutifulness, morality, sympathy and co-operation.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Right-wing authoritarianism, social dominance orientation and personality: an analysis using the IPIP measure|journal = European Journal of Personality|date = 2001-01-01|issn = 1099-0984|pages = 49–56|volume = 15|issue = 1|doi = 10.1002/per.389|first = Patrick C. L.|last = Heaven|first2 = Sandra|last2 = Bucci}}</ref> RWA is also associated with religiosity, conservativism, righteousness, and, to some extent, a conscientious moral code, which distinguishes RWA from SDO.
=== Empathy === SDO is inversely related to [[empathy]]. Facets of Agreeableness that are linked to [[altruism]], sympathy and compassion are the strongest predictors of SDO.<ref name="pratto" /> SDO has been suggested to have a link with callous affect (which is to be found on the [[psychopathy]] sub-scale), the 'polar opposite' of empathy.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = The role of "dark personalities" (narcissism, Machiavellianism, psychopathy), Big Five personality factors, and ideology in explaining prejudice|url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0092656609000658|journal = Journal of Research in Personality|date = 2009-08-01|pages = 686–690|volume = 43|issue = 4|doi = 10.1016/j.jrp.2009.02.005|first = Gordon|last = Hodson|first2 = Sarah M.|last2 = Hogg|first3 = Cara C.|last3 = MacInnis}}</ref>
The relationship between SDO and ''(lack of)'' empathy has been found to be reciprocal <ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|title = You're Inferior and Not Worth Our Concern: The Interface Between Empathy and Social Dominance Orientation|journal = Journal of Personality|date = 2013-06-01|issn = 1467-6494|pages = 313–323|volume = 81|issue = 3|doi = 10.1111/jopy.12008|pmid = 23072294|first = Jim|last = Sidanius|first2 = Nour|last2 = Kteily|first3 = Jennifer|last3 = Sheehy-Skeffington|first4 = Arnold K.|last4 = Ho|first5 = Chris|last5 = Sibley|first6 = Bart|last6 = Duriez}}</ref> – with equivocal findings. Some studies show that empathy significantly impacts SDO,<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|title = Structural Modeling of Generalized Prejudice|journal = Journal of Individual Differences|date = 2007-01-01|issn = 1614-0001|pages = 10–17|volume = 28|issue = 1|doi = 10.1027/1614-0001.28.1.10|first = Martin|last = Bäckström|first2 = Fredrik|last2 = Björklund}}</ref> whereas other research suggest the opposite effect is more robust; that SDO predicts empathy.<ref name=":2" /> The latter showcases how powerful of a predictor SDO may be, not only affecting individual's certain behaviours, but potentially influencing upstream the proneness to those behaviours. It also suggests, that those scoring high on SDO proactively avoid scenarios that could prompt them to be more empathetic or tender-minded. This avoidance decreases concern for other's welfare.<ref name=":2" />
Empathy indirectly affects generalized [[prejudice]] through its negative relationship with SDO.<ref name=":3" /> It also has a direct effect on generalized prejudice, as lack of empathy makes one unable to put oneself in the other person's shoes, which predicts prejudice and antidemocratic views.
==Correlation with conservative political views==
Felicia Pratto and her colleagues have found evidence that a high social dominance orientation is strongly correlated with [[conservatism|conservative]] political views, and opposition to programs and policies that aim to promote equality (such as [[affirmative action]], laws advocating [[Civil rights|equal rights]] for [[homosexuals]], women in combat, etc.).<ref name=pratto>{{cite journal |doi=10.1037/0022-3514.67.4.741 |title=Social dominance orientation: A personality variable predicting social and political attitudes |year=1994 |last1=Pratto |first1=Felicia |last2=Sidanius |first2=Jim |last3=Stallworth |first3=Lisa M. |last4=Malle |first4=Bertram F. |journal=Journal of Personality and Social Psychology |volume=67 |issue=4 |pages=741–63|url=http://nrs.harvard.edu/urn-3:HUL.InstRepos:3207711 }}</ref>
There has been some debate within the psychology community on what the relation is between SDO and racism/sexism. One explanation suggests that opposition to programs that promote equality need not be based on racism or sexism but on a "principled conservatism",<ref name=sidanius96>{{cite journal |doi=10.1037/0022-3514.70.3.476 |title=Racism, conservatism, Affirmative Action, and intellectual sophistication: A matter of principled conservatism or group dominance? |year=1996 |last1=Sidanius |first1=Jim |last2=Pratto |first2=Felicia |last3=Bobo |first3=Lawrence |journal=Journal of Personality and Social Psychology |volume=70 |issue=3 |pages=476–90|citeseerx=10.1.1.474.1114 }}</ref> that is, a "concern for [[Equality of opportunity|equity]], [[Color blindness (race)|color-blindness]], and genuine conservative values".
Some principled-conservatism theorists have suggested that racism and conservatism are independent, and only very weakly correlated among the highly educated, who truly understand the concepts of conservative values and attitudes. In an effort to examine the relationship between education, SDO, and racism, Sidanius and his colleagues<ref name=sidanius96 /> asked approximately 4,600 Euro-Americans to complete a survey in which they were asked about their political and social attitudes, and their social dominance orientation was assessed. "These findings contradict much of the case for the principled conservatism hypothesis, which maintains that political values that are largely devoid of racism, especially among highly educated people." Contrary to what these theorists would predict, correlations among SDO, political conservatism, and racism were strongest among the most educated, and weakest among the least educated. Sidanius and his colleagues hypothesized<ref name=sidanius96 /> this was because the most educated conservatives tend to be more invested in the hierarchical structure of society and in maintaining the inequality of the [[status quo]] in society in order to safeguard their status.
==Culture== SDO is typically measured as an individual personality construct. However, cultural forms of SDO have been discovered on the macro level of society.<ref name="Fischer 2012">{{cite journal |doi=10.1111/j.1467-9221.2012.00884.x |title=Cultural and Institutional Determinants of Social Dominance Orientation: A Cross-Cultural Meta-Analysis of 27 Societies |year=2012 |last1=Fischer |first1=Ronald |last2=Hanke |first2=Katja |last3=Sibley |first3=Chris G. |journal=Political Psychology |volume=33 |issue=4 |pages=437–67}}</ref> Discrimination, prejudice and stereotyping can occur at various levels of institutions in society, such as transnational corporations, government agencies, schools and criminal justice systems. The basis of this theory of societal level SDO is rooted in [[evolutionary psychology]], which states that humans have an evolved predisposition to express social dominance that is heightened under certain social conditions (such as group status) and is also mediated by factors such as individual personality and temperament. Democratic societies are lower in SDO measures<ref name="Fischer 2012"/> The more that a society encourages citizens to cooperate with others and feel concern for the welfare of others, the lower the SDO in that culture. High levels of national income and empowerment of women are also associated with low national SDO, whereas more traditional societies with lower income, male domination and more closed institutional systems are associated with a higher SDO. Individuals who are socialized within these traditional societies are more likely to internalize gender hierarchies and are less likely to challenge them.
==Biology and sexual differences== The biology of SDO is unknown.{{citation needed|date=November 2013}}
Plenty of evidence suggests that men tend to score higher on SDO than women, and this is true across different countries, cultures, age-groups, classes, religions and educational levels.<ref name="Sidanius1994" /> Researchers argue for an 'invariance' in the difference between men and women's SDO; suggesting that even if all other factors were to be controlled for, the difference between men and women's SDO would still remain – this however in some cases is disproved.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Inverse gender gap in Germany: Social dominance orientation among men and women|journal = [[International Journal of Psychology]] |date = 2011-02-01|issn = 1464-066X|pages = 33–45|volume = 46|issue = 1|doi = 10.1080/00207594.2010.491121|pmid = 22044131|first = Beate|last = Küpper|first2 = Andreas|last2 = Zick}}</ref>
From an evolutionary and biological perspective SDO facilitates men to be successful in their reproductive strategy through achieving social power and control over other males and becoming desired mating partners for the opposite sex.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = The Political Psychology of Reproductive Strategies|url = http://pss.sagepub.com/content/11/1/57|journal = Psychological Science|date = 2000-01-01|issn = 0956-7976|pmid = 11228844|pages = 57–62|volume = 11|issue = 1|doi = 10.1111/1467-9280.00215|first = Felicia|last = Pratto|first2 = Peter|last2 = Hegarty}}</ref>
Males are observed to be more socially hierarchical, as indicated by speaking time,<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1111/j.1468-2958.2002.tb00814.x |title=Dominance as Expressed and Inferred Through Speaking Time |year=2002 |last1=Mast |first1=Marianne Schmid |journal=Human Communication Research |volume=28 |issue=3 |pages=420–450}}</ref> and yielding to interruptions.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1177/0146167202281003 |title=Female Dominance Hierarchies: Are They Any Different from Males'? |year=2002 |last1=Mast |first1=M. S. |journal=Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin |volume=28 |pages=29–39}}</ref>
Noting that males tend to have higher SDO scores than females, Sidanius and Pratto speculate that SDO may be influenced by hormones that differ between the sexes, namely [[androgen]]s, primarily [[testosterone]]. Male levels of testosterone are much higher than that of females.
Taking a socio-cultural perspective, it is argued that the gap between women and men in SDO is dependent upon [[Norm (social)|societal norms]] prescribing different expectations for [[gender role]]s of men and women.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Gender Gaps in Sociopolitical Attitudes: A Social Psychological Analysis.|journal = Journal of Personality and Social Psychology|pages = 796–816|volume = 87|issue = 6|doi = 10.1037/0022-3514.87.6.796|first = Alice H.|last = Eagly|first2 = Amanda B.|last2 = Diekman|first3 = Mary C.|last3 = Johannesen-Schmidt|first4 = Anne M.|last4 = Koenig|pmid=15598107|year = 2004}}</ref> Men are expected to be dominant and assertive, whereas women are supposed to be submissive and tender.
Differences between male and female attributional cognitive complexity is suggested contribute to the gender gap in SDO.<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|title = Gender Differences in Social Dominance Orientation: The Role of Cognitive Complexity|journal = Sex Roles|date = 2010-04-15|issn = 0360-0025|pages = 684–692|volume = 62|issue = 9–10|doi = 10.1007/s11199-010-9775-5|first = Rob|last = Foels|first2 = Landon D.|last2 = Reid}}</ref> Women have been found to be more attributionally complex compared to men; they use more contextual information and evaluate social information more precisely. It is proposed that lower social status prompts higher cognitive complexity in order to compensate for the lack of control in that social situation by processing it more attentively and evaluating it more in depth. The difference in cognitive complexity between high and low status individuals could contribute to the differences between male and female SDO.<ref name=":4" />

{{Redirect|Status Quo|the band|Status Quo (band)|other uses|Status Quo (disambiguation)}} '''{{lang|la|Status quo}}''' is a [[list of Latin phrases|Latin phrase]] meaning the existing [[state of affairs (sociology)|state of affairs]], particularly with regard to social or political issues.<ref>[[:googledefine:status quo|"Status Quo" - Google Definitions]]</ref> In the [[Sociology|sociological]] sense, it generally applies to maintain or change existing social structure and values.<ref name=gloss>{{cite web|author1=Dr. C. Michael Botterweck|title=Glossary for Sociology 100|url=http://academics.triton.edu/faculty/mbotterweck/glossary.html|website=academics.triton.edu|accessdate=8 February 2015}}</ref> With regard to policy debate, the status quo refers to how conditions are at the time and how the affirmative team can solve these conditions for example "The countries are now trying to maintain a status quo with regards to their nuclear arsenal which will help them if the situation gets any worse."<ref>{{cite book|title=Status quo|url=http://www.theidioms.com/status-quo}}''TheIdioms.com - Online Idioms Dictionary''</ref>
It is the nominal form of the prepositional [[Latin]] phrase "{{lang|la|in statu quo}}" – literally "in the state in which", which itself is a shortening of the original phrase ''{{lang|la|[[status quo ante bellum|in statu quo res erant ante bellum]]}}'', meaning "in the state in which things were before the war". To maintain the status quo is to keep the things the way they presently are. The related phrase ''{{lang|la|[[status quo ante (disambiguation)|status quo ante]]}}'', literally "the state in which before",<ref name=dict>{{cite web|title=Status Quo Definition|url=http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/status+quo|website=dictionary.reference.com|publisher=Dictionary.com|accessdate=8 February 2015}}</ref> means "the state of affairs that existed previously".<ref name=dict/>
== Political usage ==
[[social movement|Social movements]] are an example of times when the status quo might be challenged. In these instances ''status quo'' refers to the current state of affairs around a particular issue, or perhaps the current culture or social climate of an entire [[society]] or [[nation]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.featherpicking.com/The%20Social%20Climate.htm|title=The Social Climate|accessdate=2009-03-11|work=The Optimal Environment: Part Four|publisher=www.featherpicking.com|last=Clark|first=Pamela|year=2000}}</ref> The status quo is generally perceived negatively by supporters of the social movement, and people who want to maintain the status quo can be seen as being resistant to progress.<ref name=vocab>{{cite web|title=Status Quo - Dictionary Definition|url=http://www.vocabulary.com/dictionary/status%20quo|website=vocabulary.com|publisher=vocabulary.com|accessdate=8 February 2015}}</ref>
Politicians sometimes refer to a status quo. Often there is a policy of deliberate ambiguity, referring to the status quo rather than formalizing the status. [[Clark Kerr]] is reported to have said: "The status quo is the only [[Problem solving|solution]] that cannot be [[veto]]ed".<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.il/books?id=l-w6CwAAQBAJ&lpg=PA182&ots=eXNtHsw5ex&dq=clark%20kerr%20The%20status%20quo%20is%20the%20only%20solution%20that%20cannot%20be%20vetoe&pg=PA182#v=onepage&q=clark%20kerr%20The%20status%20quo%20is%20the%20only%20solution%20that%20cannot%20be%20vetoe&f=false|title=Momentum: The Responsibility Paradigm and Virtuous Cycles of Change in Colleges and Universities|last=Seymour|first=Daniel|date=2015-12-07|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|isbn=9781475821048|language=en}}</ref>
[[Karl Marx]] viewed organized religion as a means for the [[bourgeoisie]] to keep the [[proletariat]] content with an unequal status quo,<ref name = "Boundless">Boundless. "Religion and Social Control." Boundless Sociology. Boundless, 27 Jun. 2014. Retrieved 08 Feb. 2015 [https://www.boundless.com/sociology/textbooks/boundless-sociology-textbook/religion-14/the-conflict-perspective-107/religion-and-social-control-596-2095/]</ref> and education is seen by others{{who|date=January 2018}} as a means of maintaining the status quo of society.<ref name=wikieducator>{{cite web|title=Sociology of Education|url=http://wikieducator.org/SOCIOLOGY_OF_EDUCATION|website=wikieducator.org|publisher=wikieducator.org|accessdate=8 February 2015}}</ref>

{{About|the behavioural concept|the battleship|USS Missouri (BB-63)|the rapper|Big Moe|the book|The Big Mo (book)}} '''The Big Mo''' ("Big Momentum") is [[behavioral momentum]] that operates on a large scale. The concept originally applied to sporting events in the 1960s in the United States, as momentum appeared to have an effect on a team's performance.<ref>[http://www.science20.com/sports_are_80_percent_mental/the_big_mo_psychological_momentum_in_sports Psychological momentum in sports]. See also Michael Kent, ''Oxford Dictionary of Sports Science and Medicine'', Oxford University Press, 3rd edn, 2006; [https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/football-league/crystal-palace-burnley-0-warnock-takes-big-mo-to-playoffs-821173.html Big Mo in Sports], ''The Independent''</ref> Successful teams were said to have "The Big Mo" on their side. This has since extended situations in which momentum is a driving factor, such as during political campaigns, social upheavals, economic cycles, and financial bubbles.<ref>[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/the-big-mo-how-senator-obama-gained-the-momentum-769179.html The Big Mo: How senator Obama gained the momentum]; See also Paul Kedrosky, The First Disaster of the Internet Age, ''Newsweek'', 27 October 2008. A dictionary definition is available at: http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/Big+Mo</ref>
==In modern history== The term was used by [[George H. W. Bush]] during his quest for the Republican nomination to run for President in 1980. After he won the Iowa [[caucus]]es, and was facing further contests, Bush Senior said, "Now they will be after me, howling and yowling at my heels. What we will have is momentum. We will look forward to Big Mo being on our side, as they say in athletics."<ref>Beschloss, Michael R. PBS. https://www.pbs.org/newshour/character/essays/bush.html.</ref> Eventually, Bush lost to [[Ronald Reagan]] who went on to become the 40th President of the United States.
==Impact== Research conducted in 2005, by Christopher Hull at [[Georgetown University]], US, suggested that from 1980 to 2000, "Big Mo" (large scale momentum) had amplified key events in US presidential races.<ref>[http://research.allacademic.com/meta/p_mla_apa_research_citation/0/8/5/4/5/p85453_index.html?hpsessid=92842ec13668dd0db90c44e5c128aa9d The Big Mo from 1980 to 2004: Is Technological 'e-mentum' Amplifying Key Events in Presidential Races?]</ref>
[[File:Newtons cradle animation book 2.gif|right|200px|thumb|A [[Newton's cradle]] demonstrates momentum effect.]] In 2007, three researchers from the London Business School, Elroy Dimson, Paul Marsh and Mike Staunton, observed in their paper "108 Years of Momentum Profits" that "momentum appears to have an inordinate and unexplained impact on the behaviour of investment markets that contradicts the efficient market theory". One of the researchers, Dr Paul Marsh said, "We remain puzzled (by these findings) and we are not the only ones; most academics are vaguely embarrassed by this."<ref>Elroy Dimson, Paul Marsh & Mike Staunton. Steve Johnson, Ignore Momentum at Your Peril, FT.com, viewed 20 September 2010; Research on the influence of momentum on investment markets, 108 Years of Momentum Profits. Research conducted on behalf of ABN Amro by the London Business School, February 2008</ref>
In the lead-up to the British election in May 2010, James Forsyth, the political editor of ''The Spectator'' magazine, wrote, "The Big Mo is with the [[Tories]]. In a campaign, momentum matters. It is, for good or ill, the [[Prism (optics)|prism]] through which the media report things."<ref>Forsyth, James. [http://www.spectator.co.uk/coffeehouse/5887083/the-big-mo-is-with-the-tories.thtml The Big Mo is with the Tories] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100507090657/http://www.spectator.co.uk/coffeehouse/5887083/the-big-mo-is-with-the-tories.thtml |date=2010-05-07 }}. ''The Spectator'' magazine.</ref>
In 2010, an analysis conducted by [[Mark Roeder]], a former executive at the Swiss-based [[UBS Bank]], suggested that Big Mo "played a pivotal role" in the 2008–09 [[global financial crisis]]. Roeder suggested that, {{quote|recent technological advances, such as computer-driven trading programs, together with the increasingly interconnected nature of markets, has magnified the momentum effect. This effect is not limited to the financial markets. It can be felt across other aspects of society, particularly in politics, business, technology and the media where Big Mo now operates on a massive scale.<ref>The Big Mo: Why Momentum Now Rules Our World, by Mark Roeder. HarperCollins. 2010. {{ISBN|978-0-7333-2836-7}}. Virgin Books. 2011. {{ISBN|0-7535-3937-3}}. Website: http://www.thebigmo.info. See also Bikhchandani, Sushil; Hirshleifer, David & Welch, Ivo, (1992), "A Theory of Fads, Fashion, Custom, and Cultural Change as Informational Cascades," ''Journal of Political Economy'', Volume 100, Issue 5, pp. 992–1026; Lohmann, S., 1994. The Dynamics of Informational Cascades: The Monday Demonstrations in Leipzig, East Germany, 1989–91. ''World Politics'', Vol. 47, No. 1. pp. 42–101; [http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/bandwagon "Bandwagon"]. Dictionary.com. Retrieved 2010-02-09; [http://www.teachengineering.org/view_activity.php?url=http://www.teachengineering.org/collection/cub_/activities/cub_mechanics/cub_mechanics_lesson03_activity2.xml The Big Mo: Academic analysis and engineering applications]. University of Colorado, Boulder.</ref>}}
In January 2011, a report in ''[[The Economist]]'' magazine, titled "The Big Mo", said, {{quote|The momentum effect drives a juggernaut through one of the tenets of finance theory, the efficient-market hypothesis... Even the high priests of efficient-market theory have acknowledged [its impact]. Well-paid fund managers have spent decades trying to find ways to beat the market. But you have to wonder why they bother devoting so much money and effort to researching the fortunes of individual companies when the momentum approach appears to be easy to exploit and has been around for a long time... The momentum effect raises a further important issue. If markets are rational, as the efficient-market hypothesis assumed, then they will allocate capital to its most productive uses. But the momentum effect suggests that an irrationality might be at work; investors could be buying shares (and commodities) just because they have risen in price. That would help explain why bubbles are created and why professional investors ended up allocating capital to dotcom companies with no earnings and business plans written on the back of a cigarette packet. Momentum can carry whole economies off track.<ref>''The Economist'' magazine, special report. 6 January 2011. [http://www.economist.com/node/17851295?story_id=17851295 "The Big Mo. Why Newton Was Wrong"]. See also http://www.economist.com/node/17848665</ref>}}
==Theoretical analysis== The mechanism by which momentum influences human behaviour on a large scale is not known, but a number of theories exist. In 1982, a research team led by John Nevin, [[Professor Emeritus]] of Psychology at the [[University of New Hampshire]], US, together with Charlotte Mandel and Jean Atak, wrote a paper called "The Analysis of Behavioural Momentum", in which they explored why certain behaviours can become persistent over time. The team proposed that people's tendency to continue to behave in a certain way, and resist change, is dependent on the type of reinforcement they receive. The team developed a method for calculating the impact of behavioural momentum, based on the [[Isaac Newton|Newtonian]] formula: Δ''V'' = ''f'' / ''m'', in which Δ''V'' is the change in velocity or, in behavioural terms, response rate; Velocity (''V'') refers to the response rate; mass (''m'') refers to the response strength, and force (''f'') refers to the change in the contingencies for the behaviour (i.e., environment change). The work of Nevin, Mandel and Atak has been influential in the development of social and health-care policies, such as drug rehabilitation programs, where behavioural persistence (momentum) and relapse are critical issues. <ref>Grace, R.C. (1994). Independence of reinforcement delay and magnitude in concurrent chains. ''Journal of the Experimental Analysis of Behavior'', 63, 255–276; Grace, R.C.; Bedell, M.A. & Nevin, J.A. (2002). Preference and resistance to change with constant- and variable-duration terminal links: Independence of reinforcement rate and magnitude. ''Journal of the Experimental Analysis of Behavior'', 77, 233–255.</ref>
More controversial theories about behavioural momentum derive from [[quantum physics]] and [[quantum field theory]]. In her book ''The Field'', author Lyn McTaggart cites experiments that show that in certain group environments that, "each member of the group becomes less highly-tuned to their own separate information and more receptive to that of other group members. In effect, they pick up someone else's information from the 'field' as if it were their own". She says this phenomenon is akin to what sports teams experience when they "enter the zone" and are influenced by momentum.<ref>Lynn McTaggart, ''The Field'', HarperCollins, 2001, p. 180. {{ISBN|978-0-06-143518-8}}.</ref>
==In World War II== The "Big Mo" was also the nickname for the battleship ''[[USS Missouri (BB-63)|USS Missouri]]''. This was the ship where [[Japan]] signed their surrender to the United States.
==See also== * [[Behavioral momentum]] * [[Bandwagon effect]] * [[Critical mass]] * [[Domino effect]] * [[Network effect]] * [[Virtuous circle and vicious circle]]

{{Distinguish|The Sun Also Rises}} {{italic title}} '''''The Son Also Rises''''' is a 2014 non-fiction book on the study of [[social mobility]] by the economist [[Gregory Clark (economist)|Gregory Clark]]. It is based on historical estimates of social mobility in various countries made by Clark in collaboration with other researchers, though Clark takes pains to point out from the start the controversial conclusions he draws are his alone.
The book's title, like Clark's [[A Farewell to Alms|previous book]]'s title, is a [[pun]] on the title of an Ernest Hemingway novel - in this case, ''[[The Sun Also Rises]]''.
== Content == The book follows relatively successful and unsuccessful [[extended families]] through the centuries in England, the United States, Sweden, India, China, Taiwan, Japan, Korea, and Chile. Clark uses an innovative technique of following families by seeing whether or not rare surnames kept turning up in university enrollment records, registers of physicians, lists of members of parliament, and other similar contemporary historical registers. Clark finds that the persistence of high or low [[social status]] is greater than would be expected from the generally accepted correlations of income between parents and children, conflicting with virtually all measures of social mobility previously developed by other researchers, which Clark claims are flawed. According to Clark, social mobility proceeds at a similar rate in all of the societies and in all the periods of history studied{{Spaced ndash}}with the exceptions of social groups with higher [[endogamy]] (tendency to marry within the same group), who experience higher social persistence and therefore even lower social mobility.
The book attempts to explain the difference between Clark's estimates of social mobility rates and estimates by other researchers by noting that the effects measured by other researchers are based on only a few generations, and argues that Clarke's posited [[latent variable|hidden variable]] of inherited "underlying social competence" is swamped by chance variations in status from generation to generation - variations which Clarke says are smoothed out in his longer-term study. This can be analogised to looking at a graph to understand the trend in the [[Share price|market price of a stock]]{{Spaced ndash}}a graph of a stock price over a one-day period may show large "zigzag" price swings and no apparent order, whereas a longer-term stock price graph, particularly if smoothed, may reveal a long-term trend for the price of the stock to increase or decrease.
From his finding that ethnically homogeneous societies, such as Japan and Korea, had similar rates of social mobility to ethnically diverse societies, such as the United States, Clark infers that [[racism]] may not be a significant factor affecting social mobility. From his finding that families who had many children were able to pass down their high social status just as well as families who had few children, Clark infers that simple [[inheritance]] of wealth cannot explain the persistence of high social status. From the referenced studies on the lack of correlation between the intelligence and adult family income of adopted children and their adoptive parents, Clark infers that family environment cannot explain the transmittal of social status from one generation to the next.
Clark controversially hypothesises that the main reason for the unexpectedly high persistence of social status in families (or, put another way, the unexpectedly low degree of social mobility he finds) is that high-status people are more likely to have [[genes]] that are beneficial to them achieving high status, and are therefore more likely to pass such genes on to their children.
The book also advocates a generous [[welfare state]], on the grounds that people of lower social status are unlikely to be able to advance very far in life, contrary to the widespread [[American Dream]] [[ideology]] of "anyone can make it in America if they work hard enough", and so people's advantages in life come about mostly through accident of birth, not effort.
== Reception ==
=== Scholarly === Kourtellos, Marr and Tan note that Clark's main conclusion that social mobility has always been low is supported by several other papers by other researchers.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Robust Determinants of Intergenerational Mobility in the Land of Opportunity|ssrn = 2504100|date = 1 October 2014|location = Rochester, NY|first = Andros|last = Kourtellos|first2 = Christa|last2 = Marr|first3 = Chih Ming|last3 = Tan|access-date = }}</ref>
=== Media reception === Clark wrote a February 21, 2014 ''New York Times'' article: "Your Ancestors, Your Fate".<ref name="nytimes">{{cite web|url = http://opinionator.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/02/21/your-fate-thank-your-ancestors/|title = Your Ancestors, Your Fate|publisher = The New York Times|accessdate = 2015-05-24|date = 21 February 2014}}</ref> He also wrote an article for ''[[The Guardian]]'', published a year later.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Social mobility barely exists. So don’t expect it to solve inequality|url = https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2015/feb/04/social-mobility-equality-class-society|website = [[The Guardian]]|accessdate = 2015-05-25|last = Clark|first = Gregory|date = 4 February 2015}}</ref>

{{Other uses|Toast (disambiguation)}} [[File:Hipp hipp hurra! Konstnärsfest på Skagen - Peder Severin Krøyer.jpg|thumb|300px|''[[Hip, Hip, Hurrah!]]'' by Danish painter [[P.S. Krøyer]], 1888]] A '''toast''' is a ritual in which a drink is taken as an expression of '''honor''' or '''goodwill'''. The term may be applied to the person or thing so honored, the drink taken, or the verbal expression accompanying the drink. Thus, a person could be "the toast of the evening", for whom someone "proposes a toast" to congratulate and for whom a third person "toasts" in agreement. The ritual forms the basis of the literary and performance genre, of which Mark Twain's "To the Babies" is a well-known example.{{cite web|url=http://etext.virginia.edu/railton/onstage/babies.html |title=Toast: The Babies |publisher=Etext.virginia.edu |date=2005-09-01 |accessdate=2012-04-16}} The toast as described here is rooted in [[Western culture]], but certain cultures outside that [[Cultural area|sphere]] have their own traditions in which consuming a drink is connected with ideas of celebration and honor. While the physical and verbal ritual of the toast may be elaborate and formal, merely raising one's glass towards someone or something and then drinking is essentially a toast as well, the message being one of goodwill towards the person or thing indicated. ==History== According to various apocryphal stories, the custom of touching glasses evolved from concerns about poisoning. By one account, clinking glasses together would cause each drink to spill over into the others' (though there is no real evidence for such an origin).{{cite web|url=http://www.snopes.com/food/rituals/clink.asp |title=Why We Clink Wine Glasses |publisher=snopes.com |date= |accessdate=2012-04-16}} According to other stories, the word ''toast'' became associated with the custom in the 17th century, based on a custom of flavoring drinks with spiced [[toast]]. The word originally referred to the lady in whose honor the drink was proposed, her name being seen as figuratively flavoring the drink.{{cite web |title=toast |work=Dictionary.com Unabridged (v 1.1) |publisher=Random House, Inc |url=http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/toast |accessdate=2007-08-25}}{{cite web |title=toast |work=Online Etymology Dictionary |last=Harper |first=Douglas |year=2001 |url=http://www.etymonline.com/index.php?search=toast&searchmode=term |accessdate=2007-08-25}} The ''International Handbook on Alcohol and Culture'' says toasting "is probably a secular vestige of ancient sacrificial [[libation]]s in which a sacred liquid was offered to the gods: blood or wine in exchange for a wish, a prayer summarized in the words 'long life!' or 'to your health!{{'"}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ztzcZbRaKXsC&dq=International+Handbook+on+Alcohol+and+Culture&pg=PP1#PPA81,M1 |title=International Handbook on Alcohol and Culture - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= 1995-01-01|accessdate=2012-04-16|isbn=9780313252341 }} ==Situations== [[File:US-Soviet sailors on VJ Day.jpg|thumb|right|Celebratory drinks for the end of World War II]] [[Image:Bundesarchiv Bild 183-22857-0003, Neujahrsfest.jpg|right|thumb|New Year's toast, Germany, 1953]] Toasts are generally offered at times of celebration or commemoration, including certain holidays, such as [[New Year's Eve]]. Other occasions include retirement celebrations, housewarming parties, births, etc.Boswell, Sandra. Protocol Matters: Cultivating Social Graces in Christian Homes and Schools. [[Canon Press]], 2007 p. 140 The protocol for toasting at weddings is comparatively elaborate and fixed. At a [[wedding reception]], the [[Wedding ceremony participants|father of the bride]], in his role as host, regularly offers the first toast, thanking the guests for attending, offering tasteful remembrances of the bride's childhood, and wishing the newlyweds a happy life together. The [[Wedding ceremony participants|best man]] usually proposes a toast in the form of best wishes and congratulations to the newlyweds. A best man's toast takes the form of a short speech (3–5 minutes) that combines a mixture of humor and sincerity.{{cite web |author= |url=http://www.weddingcongratulations.org/congratulations |title=Wedding Congratulations |publisher=Wedding Congratulations |date=2012-02-09 |accessdate=2012-04-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120507095100/http://www.weddingcongratulations.org/congratulations/ |archivedate=2012-05-07 |df= }} The humor often comes in the shape of the best man telling jokes at the groom's expense whilst the sincerity incorporates the praise and complimentary comments that a best man should make about the bride and groom, amongst others. The actual "toast" is then delivered at the end of the speech and is a short phrase wishing the newlyweds a happy, healthy, loving life together. The [[maid of honor]] may follow suit, appropriately tailoring her comments to the bride. The groom may offer the final toast, thanking the bride's parents for hosting the wedding, the wedding party for their participation, and finally dedicating the toast to the bridesmaids.{{cite web |url=http://www.toastchampagne.co.uk/facts/toasting.php |title=Toasting | |publisher=Toastchampagne.co.uk |date=1911-05-31 |accessdate=2012-04-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080725082717/http://www.toastchampagne.co.uk/facts/toasting.php |archivedate=2008-07-25 |df= }} Typical traditional wedding toasts include the following:{{cite web|url=http://weddings.about.com/od/theweddingparty/a/toastsamples_2.htm |title=More Samples of Wedding Toasts |publisher=Weddings.about.com |date=2012-04-09 |accessdate=2012-04-16}} {{quote|(to the couple)
Here's to your coffins
May they be made of hundred-year-old oaks
Which we shall plant tomorrow.
May you both live as long as you want, and never want as long as you live
May the best of your yesterdays be the worst of your tomorrows. (to the bride)
May I see you grey
And combing your grandchildren's hair.}} Toasts are also offered on patriotic occasions, as in the case of [[Stephen Decatur]]'s famous "Our country! In our intercourse with foreign nations may we always be in the right; but our country, right or wrong." Equally traditional are satiric verses: {{quote|Here's to dear old Boston,
The home of the bean and the cod,
Where Lowells speak only to Cabots,
And Cabots speak only to God.{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/comment/letters/3585589/Home-of-the-bean-and-the-cod.html |work=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |title=Home of the bean and the cod |date=2002-12-22 |accessdate=2010-05-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100806002501/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/comment/letters/3585589/Home-of-the-bean-and-the-cod.html |archivedate=August 6, 2010 }}}} ==Norms and etiquette of toasting== [[Image:Bride's toast.jpg|right|thumb|A bride offering a toast at a wedding]] Toasts may be solemn, sentimental, humorous, bawdy,{{cite web |url=http://www.folklore.ms/html/recitations/short_recitations/toasts/bawdy_toasts/index.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-01-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722222051/http://www.folklore.ms/html/recitations/short_recitations/toasts/bawdy_toasts/index.htm |archivedate=2011-07-22 |df= }} or insulting.{{cite web |url=http://www.folklore.ms/html/recitations/short_recitations/toasts/toasts_insulting.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-01-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722222055/http://www.folklore.ms/html/recitations/short_recitations/toasts/toasts_insulting.htm |archivedate=2011-07-22 |df= }} The practice of announcing one's intention to make a toast and signalling for quiet by rapping on the wineglass, while common, is regarded by some authorities as rude. Except in very small and informal gatherings, a toast is offered standing. At a gathering, none should offer a toast to the guest of honor until the host has had the opportunity to do so. In English-speaking countries, guests may signal their approval of the toast by saying "hear hear".{{cite web|url=http://jmarprotocol.com/helpfiles/air_force_dining.asp |title=Air Force Dining |publisher=Jmarprotocol.com |date= |accessdate=2012-04-16}} The person honored should neither stand nor drink,{{cite web|author=Goose45 |url=http://www.intowine.com/wine-toasts2.html |title=A Guide To Toasting |publisher=Into Wine |date= |accessdate=2012-04-16}} but after the toast should rise to thank the one who has offered the toast and take a drink, perhaps but not necessarily offering a toast in turn. As toasts may occur in long series, experienced attendees often make sure to leave enough wine in the glass to allow participation in numerous toasts.{{cite web|url=http://www.hmsrichmond.org/toast.htm |title=Royal Navy Toast |publisher=Hmsrichmond.org |date= |accessdate=2012-04-16}} Putting one's glass down before the toast is complete, or simply holding one's glass without drinking is widely regarded as impolite, suggesting that one does not share the benevolent sentiments expressed in the toast, nor the unity and fellowship implicit in toasting itself.{{cite web|url=http://www.bkthedj.com/wedding/wedding_traditions_history.php |title=Wedding Tradition History, Customs, Etiquette |publisher=Bkthedj.com |date= |accessdate=2012-04-16}} Even the non-drinker is counseled not to refuse to allow wine to be poured for a toast.{{cite web|url=http://www.bradley.edu/campusorg/pct/Test%20Your%20Business%20Etiquette.doc |title=Test Your Business Etiquette |publisher= |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110614052513/http://www.bradley.edu/campusorg/pct/Test%20Your%20Business%20Etiquette.doc |archivedate=2011-06-14 |df= }} Inverting the glass is especially discouraged.{{cite news |url=http://kansascity.bizjournals.com/kansascity/stories/1998/02/02/smallb2.html |first=Melinda |last=Sih |title=Minding manners at dinner serves you well in business |date=1998-02-01}} Toasting traditionally involves [[alcoholic beverage]]s.({{cite web |url=http://www.epicweddingphoto.com/toasting-traditions |title=Can you toast with non-alcoholic drinks? |date=April 2012 }}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}) [[Champagne]] (or at least some variety of [[sparkling wine]]) is regarded as especially festive and is widely associated with [[New Year's Eve]] and other celebrations.{{cite web|author=Robert J Douglas |url=http://www.bmj.com/cgi/content/full/335/7633/1281 |title=Champagne: the safer choice for celebrations |publisher=BMJ |date= |accessdate=2012-04-16}} Many people nowadays substitute sparkling fruit juice (often packaged in champagne-style bottles{{cite web |url=http://www.cincinnatisparklingjuices.com/ |title=Juice - Sparkling Juice - Meier's Wine Cellars Inc - Cincinnati - Ohio |location=39.1953; -84.4006 |publisher=Cincinnatisparklingjuices.com |date= |accessdate=2012-04-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120302154332/http://www.cincinnatisparklingjuices.com/ |archivedate=2012-03-02 |df= }}), and many authorities consider it perfectly acceptable to participate in a toast while drinking water. Toasting with an empty glass may be viewed by some as acceptable behavior for the non-drinker,{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1310&dat=19921230&id=824VAAAAIBAJ&sjid=gOoDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5496,6944063|title=Eugene Register-Guard - Google News Archive Search|publisher=}} though feigning to drink from such a glass would likely be seen as ridiculous. The person giving the toast should never do so with an empty glass, even if the glass contains nothing more than water. Teetotalers may view the drinking of toasts to be abominable and incompatible with their stand, as witnessed by this narrative from ''The Teetotaler'' (1840):
At the anniversary of Cheshunt College, [[Sir Culling Eardley, 3rd Baronet|Sir Culling Eardley Smith]] was in the chair. This gentleman, after dinner, said "he had subscribed to the Teetotal Pledge, which of course was incompatible with the drinking of toasts;" when the Rev. J. Blackburn, (minister of Claremont Chapel, Pentonville,) said "he was not a teetotaler,—''he was not in bondage,''[[Epistle to the Galatians|Galatians]] 5:1 -¶ "Stand fast therefore in the liberty wherewith Christ hath made us free, and be not entangled again with the yoke of bondage." (KJV)—and on that subject he had very recently been preaching." What could the Rev. Gentleman mean by this, but that he had recently been preaching against Teetotalism? Let the Rev. Gentleman look at drinking customs and their enormous evils, and ask himself if he has done his duty; or whether he expects to be pronounced "a [[Parable of the talents or minas|good an faithful servant]]", if he continues even from the pulpit to encourage the great damning evil of this nation. Mr. Donaldson said that he was happy to add, that one of the most popular ministers of the day, the Rev. J. Sherman, gave Mr. B. a pretty severe and well-merited reply, by saying, "His brother Blackburn had said, he (Mr. B.) was not in bondage; he must be allowed to say, that he rejoiced that he (Mr. S.) had been enabled to break through the old and stupid custom of washing down sentiments by draughts of intoxicating liquors. ''He had thus become a free man.''[[Second Epistle of Peter|2 Peter]] 2:19 - "While they promise them liberty, they themselves are the servants of corruption: for of whom a man is overcome, of the same is he brought in bondage." (KJV) Mr. Donaldson concluded with some very severe animadversions upon the infamous conduct of Mr. Blackburn.{{cite journal |date= 1840-07-25 |title= The Teetotaler |volume= I |issue= 5 |page= 38 |location= [[London]] |publisher= United Temperance Association |editor1-first= George W. M. |editor1-last= Reynolds |editor1-link= George W. M. Reynolds |accessdate= 2011-12-09 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=eABQAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA38&lpg=PA38&dq=%22incompatible+with+the+drinking+of+toasts%22#v=onepage&q=%22incompatible%20with%20the%20drinking%20of%20toasts%22&f=false |quote= he had subscribed to the Teetotal Pledge, which of course was incompatible with the drinking of toasts; |postscript= }}
It is a superstition in the [[United States Navy]] that a toast is never to be made with water, since the person so honored will be doomed to a watery grave.{{cite web|author=chicago_blogger |url=http://thewinehistorian.blogspot.com/2009/11/raditional-us-navy-wine-toast.html |title=The Wine Historian: A Traditional US Navy Wine Toast |publisher=Thewinehistorian.blogspot.com |date=2009-11-28 |accessdate=2012-04-16}} During a [[United States Air Force]] [[Dining in|Dining In]], all toasts are traditionally made with wine except for the final toast of the night made in honor of [[Prisoner of war|POWs]]/[[Missing in action|MIAs]];{{cite web|url=http://www.airforcewives.com/index.php/content/view/1125/342/ |title=MilitaryWives.com Network |publisher=Airforcewives.com |date= |accessdate=2012-04-16}} because these honorees did not have the luxury of wine while in captivity, the toast is made with water. Some versions of the protocol prescribe a toast in water for all deceased comrades. It is or was the custom on the (British) [[Royal Navy]] to drink toasts sitting, because in old-type wooden warships below decks there was not enough [[Vertical clearance|headroom]] to stand upright. ==The German word "prost"== [[File:Prost oktoberfest.jpg|right|thumb|Toasting at [[Oktoberfest]]]] === Prosit/Prost === Prosit is a [[Latin]] word from which the German short form "prost" is derived. It is a [[toast]], that is an acclamation made before drinking an alcoholic beverage when drinkers chink glasses. The expression dates back to the beginning of the 18th century when it was used among university students and eventually made its way into every day language. In a ceremonious context and in connection with a short speech, the English word [[toast]] may also be used. === Origin of the word === The word is, as mentioned above, of Latin origin and it comes from the verb "prodesse" (= "to benefit sth/sb", "to be beneficial"). Consequently, "prosit" is the [[Grammatical conjugation|conjugated]] form (3rd person Singular, Present Subjunctive, Active) and therefore an [[optative]]: "To you/ to your health". Like the colloquial "prost", "prosit" was originally used by university students.Prosit, colloquial prost in DUDEN, German Monolingual Dictionary Online === Usage === In German, [[synonyms]] like "Wohl bekomm's!", "Zum Wohl!", and many versions from other languages may also be used instead of "prosit". The acclamation itself is also referred to as a "prosit". The verb form is "zuprosten", where the prefix "zu" means that the speech act is targeted at one or several people. In the [[Swabian dialect]], the word has the further meaning of a [[belch]], called a "Prositle". The acclamation is followed by the clinking of glasses, often linked to other rules like making eye contact. This ritual is commonly attributed to a medieval custom, whereby one could avoid being poisoned by one's drinking companions, as a few drops of each beverage got mixed when clinking glasses. There is every likelihood that this did not work. It was much more effective for one table to share one or more drinking vessels, a procedure which was common for a long time. In Danish, Swedish, and Norwegian, prosit is a blessing used in response to a sneeze, in the same way the English expression "bless you" is used. In [[Germany]], toasting, not necessarily by words but usually just by touching each other's drinking vessels, is usually a very closely observed part of culture. In private company, no one should drink a sip of alcohol before having toasted all the other people at the table. In doing this, it is very important to look directly into the other drinker's eyes. Not practising this is considered rude and often, humorously, believed to attract all kinds of bad luck (e.g. "seven years of bad luck" and the like). ==Traditional toasts== In the British Royal Navy, the officers' noon mess typically began with the [[loyal toast]], followed by a toast distinctive for the day of the week: * Monday: Our ships at sea. * Tuesday: Our sailors (formerly Our men but changed to include women).{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-23013395 | work=BBC News | title='Our wives and sweethearts' Naval toast rewritten | date=2013-06-22}} * Wednesday: Ourselves. ("As no-one else is likely to concern themselves with our welfare" is often the retort and not part of the toast) * Thursday: A bloody war or a sickly season (meaning the desire and likelihood of being promoted when many people die: during war or sickness.) * Friday: A willing foe and sea room. (meaning the payment of prize money after a successful engagement) * Saturday: Our families (formerly Our wives and sweethearts with the retort of "may they never meet"). * Sunday: Absent friends. The sequence was also prescribed in at least one publication for the [[United States Navy]].US Navy's "Mess Night Manual", Naval School, Civil Engineer Corps Officers, Port Hueneme, California, August 1986 A toast might be spontaneous and free-form, a carefully planned original speech, or a recitation of traditional sentiments such as this Irish example:{{cite web|url=http://talesoftanglewood.blogspot.com/2008/07/irish-sayings-blessings-toasts.html |title=The Tales of Tanglewood: Irish Sayings, Blessings & Toasts |publisher=Talesoftanglewood.blogspot.com |date=2008-07-07 |accessdate=2012-04-16}} {{quote|May the road rise to meet you.
May the wind be always at your back.
May the sun shine warm upon your face.
And rains fall soft upon your fields.
And until we meet again,
May God hold you in the hollow of His hand.}} An informal variation of the last 2 lines is: {{quote|"And may ye be in Heaven a half-hour
afore the devil knows ye're dead!"}} ==Toasts Worldwide== In various cultures worldwide, toasting is common and to not do so may be a breach of etiquette. The general theme of a toast is "good luck" or "good health". At formal meals in certain countries of the Commonwealth of Nations, the first toast to be proposed is traditionally the [[Loyal toast|Loyal Toast]] ("[[Elizabeth II of the United Kingdom|The Queen]]"). This may be adapted in other countries to give a loyal toast to the appropriate [[Head of State]]. [[File:Pre-Meal Shots.jpg|thumb|right|Pre-meal toast in [[Mureş County]], [[Romania]]]] [[File:Toasting.JPG|thumb|right|[[Rakı]] toasting]] [[File:Pirosmani. Family party.jpg|thumb|''Family feast'' by [[Niko Pirosmani]]. (to our health) * [[Arabic language|Arabic]]: "بصحتك" (''be ṣaḥtak'', for your health) * [[Armenian language|Armenian]]: "Կենաց" or "Կենացդ" (''kenats''/''genats'' or ''kenatst''/''genatst'', "to life" or "to your life") * [[Australian English]]: Cheers bloke!
